The division between north and south post-brexit will be an EU land frontier. So long as the UK also departs from the customs union, then the border will be a trade border.
This affects not only consumers who will have limits (300 EUR a day or whatever, much like as at the airport, and as it used to be) but also companies who must declare their imports and exports for customs tariffs, VAT refunds and regulatory inspection.
There is scope for free movement of people, as is the case in the Schengen area. Several non-EU countries are part of the Schengen and can move across borders without passport or ID controls, but the goods remain tax and duty liable.
I lived some years in the south of Germany close to the Swiss border, also an EU frontier. Thanks to Schengen, people can move. Goods cannot. It’s awkward, restrictive but it’s the way it has to work.
Bandying this word “unique” around just tries to glorify the position.
There’s no way in hell the Brits would join Schengen, or anything similar.
@Pied Piper: we have a common travel area that existed long before the EU came about and this has to be maintained…..schengen isn’t needed

Of course they should be allowed a second vote, now that they know the likely true consequences of leaving. They were misled by the Leave campaigners… primarily on the false premise of saving £350m per week that they were told would be spent on NHS improvements. It has since been shown (according to what I’ve read) that is completely wrong and the net saving would be about £128m/week.
But the UK also receives billions of EU money annually – for Nth Ireland in support of the GFA, for most of its farmers, for poorer areas like Cornwall, south Wales and most of Scotland, and for its excellent science research projects that beneficially far outweighs the meagre saving of £128m/week. They will lose all those benefits.
Significant parts of the UK – Nth Ireland, West Wales, Scotland and most notably London and the greater London area, voted to remain. In fact, such was the overwhelming Remain vote in the London area that it was even mooted that London could leave the UK and establish a Republic of London enclave within the UK that would remain part of the EU. Its population is about 9m, over twice that of the Irish Republic and the idea of a Rep of London remaining in the EU is not to be sniffed at. There are too many global businesses based in London who would leave the city to remain part of the EU that it would seriously impact the overall UK economy.
Scotland voted to Remain and it wishes to further establish its independence outside the UK and remain part of the EU. Nth Ireland voted to Remain part of the EU. If only its die-hard Unionists would cop on to the fact that there is no threat to themselves within a united Ireland under the Irish Constitution and live happily alongside us all, it would make such a big difference to the desire of the majority of Nth Ireland voters to remain in the EU. They really should not worry – after all, there are so many British citizens happily living, working and running businesses in West Cork that Corkonians jokingly refer to West Cork as the new Republic of England.
The people who carried the UK’s Leave vote were staunch hinterland Englanders who still believe in the notion of a now-defunct British Empire, not really in tune with today’s realities, and those worried by the influx of Muslims, Pakistanis, Indians, East Euorpeans, Carribean people and people of the African Continent who were part of the old British Empire who they see as eroding native British culture (a fair point… we see it here in Ireland too).
Now that the real impact and consequences of leaving the EU are becoming more apparent, of course the UK people should be given a chance to vote again.
The real truth is that ‘Engerlanders’ will become isolated from not just the European Community but more so from the global community. Stark reality, stark fact.

The only thing that made the border an irrelevance was both countries EU membership.
It’s beyond ludicrous and really an absolute contortion of logic to try to turn the UK unilaterally leaving the EU into the NI border somehow being the EU’s fault.
The British and Irish states had a customs border from 1923 to 1993, when the single market was completed to a level that removed intra EU customs entirely.
It was that change that made the border finally disappear entirely and with the improved security situation in the 1990s it vanished entirely as it was irrelevant.
The CTA never covered movement of goods and services and if that’s what we’re falling back to, we will see a NI border that looks as it did before 1993, just without the active security issues.
People are misremembering (I suspect quite deliberately) how things worked between Ireland and the UK pre-EU and before the Single European Market. There was no UK-Irish customs union and you got stopped at the border with your shopping.
I suspect that the aim in the Brexit camp will be to attempt to blame the EU for Northern Ireland’s situation and divert attention from the fact that it’s being caused by UK isolationist politics.
Northern Ireland is probably the best example of how the EU allows borders not to matter and created an environment where a conflict about national identity and sovereignty could be cooled, calmed and a way of coexisting became more possible.
Brexit is just a return to old-school nationalism and with that comes borders!

Part of the problem is that if you have regulatory “convergence” between NI and the Republic then you either have divergence with the rest of the UK or you have convergence between the whole of the UK and the EU.
At that point the UK is able to trade with the EU but is hamstrung in terms of being able to make trade deals with the rest of the world.
So trade with the EU, no say in EU regulations, regulated by the ECJ, no say in the ECJ, paying into the EU, no say in the EU.
You can see that that wouldn’t be ideal for anyone, particularly not for a nation look to take back control. Because it’s the exact opposite of taking back control.

EU labour markets.

Rhetorical or not, it isn’t that hard. EU member states are parliamentary democracies. And apart from the UK, there simply haven’t been enough parliamentary votes to force such referendums to take place.
As for this ‘superstate’, this idea is entertained by europhiles like Martin Schulz, but I see this as a professional deformity – in his case due to having been head of the EU parliament. Federalism doesn’t have the necessary traction among sufficient numbers of voters in member states, quite the contrary. But not wanting federalism is not the same as wanting to leave the EU.

I’ve got to admit: I’ve had a somewhat rosy view of things, but I’m less sure now. Initially there was going to be a ‘special status’ for Northern Ireland, until the DUP complained: no sort of border in the Irish Sea.
When that was fixed, my rosy view was the Irish and the Northern Irish together holding the door open to the rest of the UK. They’d be staying in the customs union and the single market in all but name, thanks to this magical notion of ‘alignment’.
But now it seems as if the EU has felt compelled to satisfy the hard Brexiteers, by allowing the notion of ‘alignment’ to be effectively filled in via a free trade deal. Which means that the Good Friday Agreement becomes a bargaining chip in order for Britain to get not only access to Ireland, but by extension to the entire EU.

Actually there are two borders to be considered…. crossing from UK via NI into the EU via Ireland and crossing from the EU via Ireland into the UK via NI.
If the EU and Ireland accepts that anyone can important anything from Northern Ireland without payment of customs duties or taxes (as in anything they can import today without taxes) and that there is a free movement of people and services then the EU through Ireland will not have to implement a hard border on North South traffic
If the UK accepts the free movement of people, goods and services into NI then they will not have to implement a hard border on South North traffic.
Neither of these are consistent with EU non-EU traffic and, as the article says “these positions have been irreconcilable” – and I have yet to hear anyone say how they could be ….

The Brits import 40 billion more from the EU then they export . To deny them access to the single market would a act of self harm . Iceland and Liechtenstein are also members of the EEA.

But to allow it would also be an act of self harm, as the Brits want to stop migration, which they ultimately won’t, but it was the whole point of Brexit.
Norway allows free movement. Note that it also had an EU referendum that went 52-48%, but it’s in the EEA because the country compromised in recognition of their 48%, something the British govt is incapable of.
The EU can’t allow its fundamental freedoms to be harmed because of this.

@Tommy Whelan: they won’t join the EEA, which would be the most obvious solution, because they won’t accept the “four freedoms” – free movement of persons, goods, services and capital. While the British Labour Party are setting a good democratic example to other countries – such as Ireland who just seek to overturn inconvenient referendum results – by accepting Brexit, the call by Jeremy Corbyn for his country to stay very close to single market rules post-Brexit (a country cannot leave the EU and still be officially part of the single market and the customs union, for they are one and the same) is intellectually-inconsistent for a man of the Left. This is so, because the single market mitigates against individual states bringing in greater labour laws and regulations. That is why it is surprising that Mr Corbyn is adopting this political approach, but it wouldn’t be surprising if he is doing it only half-heartedly (just as he campaigned for the UK to remain in the EU only half-heartedly).

This may open the door for UKIP to re-emerge as a force in UK politics, as many of the British Labour Party’s white working-class voters will be very disappointed at this volte-face by Labour. Millions of these voters only recently felt it was safe to return to the UK Labour Party, now under Corbyn, because they believed that the issue of full withdrawal from the European Union (including the Single Market, of which free movement of people is a requirement for access) was settled. Full withdrawal from the EU and Single Market is still on course to happen, as per the wishes of the UK electorate in the referendum on this matter, because the current Conservative Party government is committed to it. But many working class voters might no longer trust the Labour Party, as a result of this volte-face by the party.

Brexit is bad in every respect for Nothern Ireland, it is worst of all for Northern Ireland, it is bad for Great Britain and it is bad for Ireland.

Let’s look at this in perspective. The reduction in the US Tax rate will make very little difference to US Multinationals based here, (a) our Corporate Tax rate is still 10% lower and (b) to gain unimpeded access to EU markets they need to have a base within the EU. Now for Brexit, by the end of 2019 companies will have had over 3 years to prepare for Brexit. Any company that has not prepared itself in that time for the worst case scenario is being run by Imbeciles. Take the case of the Agri/food sector. The UK population still needs to eat after Brexit. And new trade deals take time to negotiate. So unless the UK plan on rationing they will still require all the current food they import. In the Service Sector we could gain, as UK based firms depart for the EU.

@Sandra O’Fucáif: Sandra by sourcing food elsewhere they would be doing so under WTO tarriffs with no guarantee of quality or standards as currently enjoyed by the UK public as part of the EU. Added to that, what damage will be done to UK agriculture. Under the EU umbrella UK farming is protected. Prices are stable, subsidies are available. When they leave that protection is gone. Let’s say they begin importing cheap Ukranian grain. The price of UK grain is going to have to fall to match it, making already struggling arable farmers go out of business. Likewise say cheap Brazilian beef, Australian Mutton, Chinese Garlic. Currently the UK needs to import 48% of its food needs. As UK farmers are priced out that % will increase exponentially.

Indigenous Dubliners and people 50 or more kilometers away from the border counties are generally unaware of the daily physical inconveniences and funny economy experienced by people in Donegal, Leitrim, Monaghan, Cavan and Louth as a result of partition between 1925 and 1998. I think that Ireland has to play a far more constructive role in the Brexit negotiating process than we are currently doing. Not for the first time, we are allowing ourselves to be used as pawns by the EU bureaucracy (in this case, by Michel Barnier and Jean Claude Juncker) in their efforts to stall and, vindictively, make life as difficult as possible for the British, who made a democratic decision to leave the European Union (democracy is not something that the Brussels bureaucracy always smiles upon). A hard border is really two borders as in North-South and South-North…. it is easy for the UK to say that they will not have a hard border, as in no border controls going from South (EU) to North (Non-EU) and they have promised that in the event of no agreement. However the EU also need to state that they will not have any border controls going from the North (Non-EU) to the South (EU) and that has not happened…
What we are seeing was as clear as day, you cannot have no border North-South and South-North and have different rules apply North and South.
These rules include things like what can be added to food and the food chain, working hours, labour conditions, quality of goods, quality control, import charges on goods from outside the UK and EU (and who they should be paid to) and a host of things that are covered by the various EU rules and regulations….
I think for the first time we are seeing people starting to talk the truth about all this….

Anyone who thinks that the UK will retain “full regulatory alignment” I think underestimates what “full regulatory alignment” actually means…… in a nutshell the EU could decide anything (for example a EU minimum wage, or 30 days annual leave ) and the UK would have to introduce legislation at Westminster to implement any EU legislation (like a UK minimum wage to match an EU minimum wage in that example, or minimum holidays, etc.) as failure to do that would give the UK employers an advantage – and the purpose of regulatory alignment is to ensure that the UK has no advantage over other EU countries.
Hard to see that happening over the years and different UK governments – maintaining full regulatory alignment is an ongoing task and not a once off thing – as EU regulations change so to would UK regulations – or the system falls apart.

In the negotiations between the EU and Britain it has been one way traffic, the EU puts forward it’s position on an issue, the British huff and puff and bluster for a while and then agree to what the EU has put forward.
In relation to the border between here and the North, there are several options on the table, a hard Brexit being one of them, but to me the crucial comment by Barnier was this:
“The third option is to maintain full regulatory alignment with those rules of the single market and the customs union, current or future, that support north-south cooperation, the all-island economy and the Good Friday agreement.
It is our responsibility to include the third option in the text of the withdrawal agreement to guarantee there will be no hard border whatever the circumstances.”
